prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for dumping my gf after her unannounced backpacking trip
Ok so this happened maybe three days ago, but first some context.

Me and my (now ex) girlfriend of 3 years lived in a 2 bedroom apartment which I pay for by myself, as I make enough money to afford it and I didn’t want to trouble her by pressing her with a bill for a place that is a tiny bit out of her price range, instead we use a meter and pay the bill through my account, with her compensating her  spend.
 
We also have always been big on trust since both of us have been cheated on in previous relationships, and didn’t want to go through that again in this one.

The fact that I pay solely this apartment is important as it allows her to spend her money on things like more expensive gifts and the occasional excursion for us (which of course I pay in part for). Also the fact that we are big on trust means we tell eachother A lot about our lives and future plans.

Anyways, she was always a fan of these trips abroad and loved travelling, and for the most part our trips were always fun. However, about three days ago she announced that she had bought tickets for a solo backpacking trip across South America which she was going to go on on Friday, and that she had been planning this for months.

First I asked if I could come, to which she said no because she would be “discovering herself” on this trip, and when I asked why hadn’t she told me she said because I wouldn’t have allowed (or at the very least not wanted) her to go, especially alone.  (Which is mostly true)

Well an argument ensued and at some point I finally put my foot down, it went something like this: 

Gf: “why can’t I just go explore the world and live life to its fullest”

Me: “you can, without me or the security of my home, pack your bags and get out”

I believe it was the right thing to do as she didn’t pay for the apartment anyways, and so didn’t have any right to demand to stay, plus I was willing to give her money for a hotel for a week, which she refused.

That night she went to her parents home an hour away and my phone was blown up with people calling me a controlling asshole and the like, my question is am I really an asshole for this?

TLDR: girlfriend popped a surprise solo trip on me 5 days before she left, saying she wanted to go alone and had been planning it for months, I kicked her out my house. 


"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is that the girlfriend planned a solo backpacking trip without telling him, and when he found out, he kicked her out of their apartment because she wasn't paying for it. The main points to consider are communication, trust, and the living arrangement.

First, the apartment is paid for by the author alone, and the girlfriend compensates him for her share. They've been in a 3-year relationship with trust being a big part. The girlfriend wanted to go on a solo trip, which he didn't agree with. She said she was going to go despite his disapproval because she wanted to "discover herself." When he confronted her, he told her to leave the house if she wanted to go. She left and stayed with her parents. Now he's being accused of being controlling.

Hmm. The key issue here is communication. The girlfriend didn't tell him about the trip she had been planning for months. That's a problem because they were supposed to be open with each other. However, the author's reaction was to kick her out. That seems harsh, even if the apartment is his. Maybe he overreacted? 

But then again, if she wasn't paying for the apartment, maybe he felt justified in asking her to leave if she wasn't part of the agreement. However, relationships require mutual respect. Even if she didn't pay for the apartment, she's part of the relationship, and her decision to go on a solo trip might be a personal choice. The fact that he used the living arrangement as leverage might have been a mistake. 

Also, the argument about control comes into play. By threatening to ask her to leave if she didn't comply with his wishes, he might be seen as controlling. But if he's the one paying for the apartment, does he have the right to set boundaries? It's complicated. 

Another angle: the girlfriend didn't communicate her plans, which is a breach of trust. But the author's response was to end the relationship by kicking her out. Maybe he should have tried to talk it through instead of using the house as a bargaining chip. 

In terms of right or wrong, the girlfriend's lack of communication is definitely a problem. But the author's reaction could be seen as excessive. Ending the relationship over a disagreement about a trip, even if it's unannounced, might be too much. They might have resolved it without breaking up. 

So, considering all that, I think the author is partly at fault for overreacting. The right approach would have been to discuss the issue and find a compromise, not to use the house as a tool to force her hand. Therefore, the answer might lean towards A, that he's in the wrong.
